citation.article-title: Lactobacillus fornicalis sp. nov., isolated from the posterior fornix of the human vagina.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Lactobacillus fornicalis sp. nov.
Lactobacillus fornicalis(for.nic.a'lis. L. gen. n. fornicalis of the posterior fornix)
Colonies on MRS agar are round, smooth, white and approximately 1 mm in diameter.
Growth occurs at temperatures between 20 and 40 °C on MRS agar, with the optimum temperature between 35 and 37 °C.
Facultatively anaerobic, but grows well on the surface of MRS agar when not incubated under microaerophilic conditions.
Obligately homofermentative, with no gas production from glucose or gluconate. d(-)- and l-lactic acid are produced from glucose.
Indole is not formed and nitrates are not reduced.

Polysaccharides are not produced from sucrose. Lactobacillus fornicalis is distinguished from L. johnsonii, L. acidophilus, L. gallinarum, L. crispatus, L. gasseri and L. jensenii on the basis of a few carbohydrate fermentation reactions (Table 2).
Acid is produced from amygdalin, cellobiose, fructose, galactose, glucose, maltose, mannose, mannitol, melezitose, ribose, salicin, sorbitol, sucrose and trehalose.
Arabinose, lactose, melibiose, raffinose, rhamnose, starch and xylose are not fermented.
The G­+C content of the type strain is 37 mol% (as determined by the thermal denaturation method).
Isolated from the posterior fornix fluid of the human vagina.
